question: How long does it take Earth to complete one orbit around the Sun?

content.source_1: In astronomy, a planet’s revolution period is the time required to complete one full orbit around its star.
content.source_2: Earth orbits the Sun; one complete orbit (the tropical year) takes about 365.2422 days.
content.source_3: A solar day is the interval between successive local noons and is roughly 24 hours long.
content.source_4: From one solar noon to the next, Earth has completed one full turn relative to the Sun, bringing the Sun back to the same meridian.
content.source_5: Earth’s rotation period relative to distant stars (the sidereal day) is about 23 hours 56 minutes.
content.source_6: Because Earth advances about 1 degree along its orbit each day, the solar day is about 4 minutes longer than the sidereal day.
